title: 103_hr929
content: The text chunk discusses the simplification of employment taxes on domestic services by increasing the threshold requirement from $50 to $300. It also addresses the coordination of collection of domestic service employment taxes with the collection of income taxes. The text outlines the rules for filing returns for domestic service employment taxes on a calendar year basis. It specifies the deadline for filing returns and exempts the requirement for deposits or installment payments. Additionally, it discusses how domestic service employment taxes are subject to estimated tax provisions and may be treated as a tax imposed by chapter 2 for the taxable year of the employer. Adjustments can be made in the application of section 6654(d)(2) under regulations prescribed by the Secretary. The text discusses the rules for filing domestic service employment taxes on a calendar year basis. It includes provisions for adjustments in tax application and defines domestic service employment taxes. The text outlines regulations for domestic service employment taxes, including exceptions for employers liable for other employment taxes and the Secretary's authority to enter agreements for collecting state unemployment taxes. The Secretary is authorized to enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in private homes. Taxes collected will be treated as domestic service employment taxes and transferred to the state's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. This authority applies to taxes imposed by chapter 23, with the term 'State' defined as per section 3306(j)(1). Any amount collected under an agreement shall be treated as a tax imposed by chapter 23. The term 'State' is defined as per section 3306(j)(1). The amendments made by this section apply to remuneration paid in calendar years after 1993.
